The '''National Occupational Research Agenda''' (NORA) is a partnership program developed by the [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]] (NIOSH). The program was founded in 1996 to provide a framework for research collaborations among universities, large and small businesses, professional societies, government agencies, and worker organizations. Together these parties identify issues in the field of [[Occupational safety and health|workplace safety and health]] that require immediate attention based on the number of workers affected, the seriousness of the hazard, and the likelihood that new safety information and approaches can effect a change.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/NORA/ National Occupational Research Agenda (NORA)], National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. Retrieved on 2008-08-10.</ref>
==Developing the first research agenda==
Dr. [[Linda Rosenstock]] was appointed director of NIOSH in 1994. At that time many saw the Institute as an agency that yielded strong scientific research, but needed stronger connections to the real-world workforce.<ref name=ucla>[http://www.ph.ucla.edu/magazine/winter2001.pdf "From Washington to Westwood: New Dean Brings Her Public Health Vision to UCLA"], ''UCLA School of Public Health Newsletter'' Volume 21, Number 1, Winter 2001.</ref> To remedy this, Rosenstock sought to develop stronger relationships with other organizations and agencies. NIOSH moved its headquarters from [[Atlanta]] to [[Washington, D.C.]], where the Institute could enjoy closer contact with labor and industry representatives.<ref name="washam">Washam, Cynthia. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1469368/pdf/envhper00336-0032-color.pdf "Working Toward a New NIOSH"], ''Environmental Health Perspectives'' Volume 104, Number 5, May 1996. Retrieved on 2008-08-12</ref> NIOSH's effort to build partnerships inside and outside of the government culminated in the development of the National Occupational Research Agenda.
To form the agenda, NIOSH leaders petitioned stakeholders in industry, labor, and health care for input. Organizations including [[General Motors]], [[IBM]], [[Mobil]], the [[United Auto Workers]], and the [[American Public Health Association]] joined NIOSH in developing the agenda. NIOSH sought additional aid through a series of public town meetings held in [[Chicago]], [[Seattle]], and [[Boston]].<ref name=washam/> In total, nearly 500 organizations and individuals provided the input that resulted in the research agenda.<ref>Rosenstock, Linda. [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/B6VT3-3YVDPKC-6/2/6662a6ae1876f9bcc3adabd9778b53bf "Remarks of Dr. Linda Rosenstock, Howard-Fawcett award recipient"], ''Chemical Health and Safety'' Volume 7, Issue 2, March-April 2000, pages 7-9. Retrieved on 2007-08-12.</ref>
==NORA in practice==
NIOSH announced NORA's 21 priority research areas in 1996. On the strength of industry support and bipartisan backing, [[United States Congress|Congress]] increased funding for NIOSH and investment in NORA grew from $15.4 million in 1996 to $72.3 million in 1999.<ref name=ucla/> Following Rosenstock's resignation in 2000, Dr. John Howard continued to press and expand the NORA approach as NIOSH's new director.<ref>Nash, James. [http://www.occupationalhazards.com/News/Article/35587/John_Howard_Appointed_New_Director_of_NIOSH.aspx "John Howard Appointed New Director of NIOSH"], ''Occupational Hazards'' 2002-06-25. Retrieved on 2008-08-12.</ref> Periodically, the structure of the program is evaluated and updated as needed. Since 1996, NORA's projects have covered topics such as [[slip and fall|slip, trip, and fall]] (STF) injuries; [[Green Tobacco Sickness|green tobacco sickness]]; extended work hours; [[latex allergy|latex allergies]]; vehicle and mobile equipment-related injury; [[silicon dioxide|silica]], [[lung cancer]], and [[respiratory disease]]; and biomechanical stress in drywall installation.<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/pastnora.html "Celebrating NORA, 1996-2006"], National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. Retrieved on 2008-08-10.</ref>
== NORA's Research Organization: Sectors and Cross-Sectors == Since 2006, the program has been organized by industrial sector as defined in the [[North American Industry Classification System]]. NORA sector councils, which head the research for the sectors, help to implement the national research agenda.<ref name="guide">"About Nora...Partnerships, Research, and Practice." [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/about.html NIOSH Website]. 10-21-08.</ref> The accomplishments of the second decade of NORA are described in a [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2017-146/pdfs/2017-146.pdf report] published in 2017. NORA councils consists of participants from various backgrounds, affiliations and expertise, including stakeholders from universities, large and small businesses, professional associations, government agencies, and worker organizations. Councils present the opportunity to maximize resources towards improved occupational safety and health nationwide. They help build close partnerships among members and broader collaborations between councils and other organizations. The resulting information sharing and leveraging efforts helps promote widespread adoption of improved workplace practices based on research results. The NORA industry sector councils for the 2016-2026 decade are as follows:<ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2007-118/ "The Nation's Investment in Occupational Safety and Health Research"], DHHS (NIOSH) Publication No. 2007-118. Retrieved on 2008-08-12.</ref><ref>[https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/sectorprograms.html CDC - National Occupational Research Agenda (NORA): NORA Council], National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. Retrieved on 2013-09-10.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/sectorapproach.html|title=CDC - National Occupational Research Agenda (NORA): Sectors|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref>
* [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/councils/agff/default.html Agriculture, forestry, and fishing] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/councils/const/default.html Construction] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/councils/hcsa/default.html Healthcare and social assistance] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/sectors/manuf/default.html Manufacturing] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/councils/mining/default.html Mining] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/councils/oilgas/default.html Oil and gas extraction] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/sectors/pubsaf/ Public safety] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/sectors/serv/ Services] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/sectors/twu/ Transportation, warehousing and utilities] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/councils/wrt/default.html Wholesale and retail trade]
In addition, NIOSH identified seven cross-sectors which focus on the health and safety issues affecting workers within each sector. The current NORA health outcome cross-sectors include:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/crosssectors.html|title=CDC - National Occupational Research Agenda (NORA): Cross-sectors|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref> * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/crosssectors/crc/default.html Cancer, Reproductive, Cardiovascular, and other Chronic Disease Prevention] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/crosssectors/crc/default.html Hearing Loss Prevention] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/crosssectors/iid/default.html Immune, Infectious, and Dermal Disease Prevention] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/crosssectors/mus/default.html Musculoskeletal Health] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/crosssectors/resp/default.html Respiratory Health] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/crosssectors/ti/default.html Traumatic Injury Prevention] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/nora/councils/hwd/default.html Healthy Work Design and Well-Being]
===NORA priorities=== To aid with goal-setting, NORA uses specific guidelines to determine which research needs are priorities, by using use concepts of burden, need, and impact criteria to write research goals that go into NORA Sector and Cross-Sector Agendas. These guidelines basically address these aspects:<ref name=guide/> *number of workers at risk for illness or injury *severity of the hazard/issue *probability that new information will help abate the hazard
== NORA results == Every ten years, NIOSH reviews the activities, outcomes, and impacts of work completed over the past NORA decade and completes a report of those accomplishments. The first decade report evaluated contributions from 1996-2006,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2006-121/|title=CDC - NIOSH Publications and Products - NORA: The Team Document (2006-121)|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref> while the second decade report reviewed activities from 2006-2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2017-146/|title=National Occupational Research Agenda: Second Decade in Review {{!}} 2006–2016|date=2017-07-18|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref> NORA's third decade will occur from 2016-2026.
== NORA symposiums == To ensure a continued focus on the practical application of the research, NIOSH cosponsored NORA Symposiums in 1999, 2003, 2006, and 2008. The 2008 NORA Symposium—"Public Market for Ideas and Partnerships"—was the first not held in the Washington, D.C., area. Instead it was hosted in [[Denver]], reflecting NIOSH's desire to expand occupational research collaborations in the Western United States.<ref>[https://ohsonline.com/Articles/2008/07/NORA-Symposium-to-Highlight-Safety-Research-Partnerships.aspx "NORA Symposium to Highlight Safety Research Partnerships"], ''Occupational Health & Safety'' Magazine 2008-07-15. Retrieved on 2008-08-12.</ref>
==External links==
[https://www.census.gov/epcd/www/naics.html North American Industry Classification System (NAICS)], U.S. Census Bureau.

'''National health insurance''' ('''NHI''') – sometimes called '''statutory health insurance''' ('''SHI''') – is a system of [[health insurance]] that insures a national population against the costs of [[health care]]. It may be administered by the public sector, the private sector, or a combination of both. Funding mechanisms vary with the particular program and country. National or Statutory health insurance does not equate to government-run or government-financed health care, but is usually established by national legislation. In some countries, such as Australia's [[Medicare (Australia)|Medicare]] system, the UK's [[National Health Service]], and the South Korea’s [[National Health Insurance Corporation]] contributions to the system are made via general taxation and therefore are not optional even though use of the health system it finances is. In practice, most people paying for NHI will join it. Where the NHI involves a choice of multiple insurance funds, the rates of contributions may vary and the person has to choose which insurance fund to belong to. ==History== Germany has the world's oldest national social health insurance system,{{cite web|last=Bump|first=Jesse B.|date=October 19, 2010|title=The long road to universal health coverage. A century of lessons for development strategy|location=Seattle|publisher=[[Program for Appropriate Technology in Health|PATH]]|url=http://www.rockefellerfoundation.org/uploads/files/23e4426f-cc44-4d98-ae81-ffa71c38e073-jesse.pdf|accessdate=March 10, 2013|quote=Carrin and James have identified 1988—105 years after Bismarck’s first sickness fund laws—as the date Germany achieved universal health coverage through this series of extensions to minimum benefit packages and expansions of the enrolled population. Bärnighausen and Sauerborn have quantified this long-term progressive increase in the proportion of the German population covered by public and private insurance. Their graph is reproduced below as Figure 1: German Population Enrolled in Health Insurance (%) 1885–1995.}}
{{cite journal|last1=Carrin|first1=Guy|last2=James|first2=Chris|date=January 2005|title=Social health insurance: Key factors affecting the transition towards universal coverage|journal=International Social Security Review|volume=58|issue=1|pages=45–64|url=http://www.who.int/health_financing/documents/shi_key_factors.pdf|accessdate=March 10, 2013|quote=Initially the health insurance law of 1883 covered blue-collar workers in selected industries, craftspeople and other selected professionals.6 It is estimated that this law brought health insurance coverage up from 5 to 10 per cent of the total population.|doi=10.1111/j.1468-246x.2005.00209.x}}
{{cite journal|last1=Bärnighausen|first1=Till|last2=Sauerborn|first3=Rainer|date=May 2002|title=One hundred and eighteen years of the German health insurance system: are there any lessons for middle- and low income countries?|journal=Social Science & Medicine|volume=54|issue=10|pages=1559–1587|doi=10.1016/S0277-9536(01)00137-X|pmid=12061488|url=http://www.ministerial-leadership.org/sites/default/files/resources_and_tools/10%20german%20health%20insu.pdf|accessdate=March 10, 2013|quote=As Germany has the world’s oldest SHI [social health insurance] system, it naturally lends itself to historical analyses.}} with origins dating back to [[Otto von Bismarck]]'s Sickness Insurance Law of 1883.{{cite book|last=Leichter|first=Howard M.|year=1979|title=A comparative approach to policy analysis: health care policy in four nations|location=Cambridge|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=cfI6AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA121 121]|isbn=0-521-22648-1|quote=The Sickness Insurance Law (1883). Eligibility. The Sickness Insurance Law came into effect in December 1884. It provided for compulsory participation by all industrial wage earners (i.e., manual laborers) in factories, ironworks, mines, shipbuilding yards, and similar workplaces.}}{{cite book|last=Hennock|first=Ernest Peter|year=2007|title=The origin of the welfare state in England and Germany, 1850–1914: social policies compared|location=Cambridge|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=6QysFcGNcBUC&pg=PA157 157]|isbn=978-0-521-59212-3}} In Britain, the [[National Insurance Act 1911]] included national social health insurance for primary care (not specialist or hospital care), initially for about one third of the population—employed working class wage earners, but not their dependents.{{cite book|last=Leathard|first=Audrey|year=2000|chapter=Health care in Britain: pre-war provision, 1900–1939|title=Health care provision: past, present, and into the 21st century|edition=2nd|location=Cheltenham|publisher=Stanley Thornes|pages=3–4|isbn=9780748733545|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=D2lVXWNQ7ZsC&pg=PA3}} This system of health insurance continued in force until the creation of the [[National Health Service]] in 1948 which created a universal service, funded out of general taxation rather than on an insurance basis, and providing health services to all legal residents. ==Types of programs== {{See also|Health care systems|Single-payer health care|Universal health care}} National healthcare insurance programs differ both in how the money is collected, and in how the services are provided. In countries such as Canada, payment is made by the government directly from tax revenue. The collection is administered by government. This is known in the [[United States]] as [[single-payer health care]]. The provision of services may be through either publicly or privately owned health care providers. In France a similar system of compulsory contributions is made, but the collection is administered by non-profit organisations set up for the purpose. An alternative funding approach is where countries implement national health insurance by legislation requiring compulsory contributions to competing insurance funds. These funds (which may be run by public bodies, private for-profit companies, or private non-profit companies), must provide a minimum standard of coverage and are not allowed to discriminate between patients by charging different rates according to age, occupation, or previous health status. To protect the interest of both patients and insurance companies, the government establishes an [[equalization pool]] to spread risks between the various funds. The government may also contribute to the equalization pool as a form of health care subsidy. This is the model used in the Netherlands. Other countries are largely funded by contributions by employers and employees to sickness funds. With these programs, funds come from neither the government nor direct private payments. This system operates in countries such as [[Germany]] and [[Belgium]]. These funds are usually not for profit institutions run solely for the benefit of their members. Usually characterization is a matter of degree: systems are mixes of these three sources of funds (private, employer-employee contributions, and national/sub-national taxes). In addition to direct medical costs, some national insurance plans also provide compensation for loss of work due to ill-health, or may be part of wider [[social insurance]] plans covering things such as pensions, unemployment, occupational retraining, and financial support for students. National schemes have the advantage that the pool or pools tend to be very very large and reflective of the national population. Health care costs, which tend to be high at certain stages in life such as during pregnancy and childbirth and especially in the last few years of life can be paid into the pool over a lifetime and be higher when earnings capacity is greatest to meet costs incurred at times when earnings capacity is low or non existent. This differs from the private insurance schemes that operate in some countries which tend to price insurance year on year according to health risks such as age, family history, previous illnesses, and height/weight ratios. Thus some people tend to have to pay more for their health insurance when they are sick and/or are least able to afford it. These factors are not taken into consideration in NHI schemes. In private schemes in competitive insurance markets, these activities by insurance companies tend to act against the basic principles of insurance which is group solidarity. ==National health insurance programs== {{see also|Universal health coverage by country}} * [[Aasandha]] - Maldives * [[Health care in Australia]] - [[Medicare (Australia)]] * [[Healthcare in Belgium]] - Sickness and Invalidity Insurance * [[Health care in Canada]] * [[Health care in Colombia]] - Law 100 - National Health Insurance Scheme: Contributory Vs. Subsidized coverage (NHIS) * [[Health care in France]] * [[Healthcare in Germany]] * [[Health care in Ghana]] - National Health Insurance Scheme (NHIS) * [[National Health Insurance (Japan)|Health care in Japan]] - People without insurance through employers can participate in a national health insurance program administered by local governments. * [[Healthcare in Nigeria]] - National Health Insurance Scheme (NHIS) * [[Health care in the Netherlands]] * [[Healthcare in the Philippines]] - Social Health Insurance Program, a resource pooling, risk sharing health care program that provides quality health care financing not only to the employed but to the sick, elderly, and indigents, as well * [[Health care in Poland]] * [[Healthcare in South Korea]] * [[Healthcare in Switzerland]] - A compulsory health insurance covers a range of treatments which are set out in detail in the Federal Act. * [[Healthcare in Taiwan]] - National Health Insurance (NHI) *[[Health care in the United Kingdom]] - National Insurance {{expand list|date=November 2018}} ==See also== *[[Health care compared]] - tabular comparisons of the US, Canada, and other countries not shown above. *[[Health care politics]] *[[Publicly funded health care]] *[[Single-payer health care]] *[[Universal health care]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *Nicholas Laham: ''Why the United States lacks a national health insurance program'', Westport, Conn. [u.a.] : Greenwood Press, 1993 *Barona, B., Plaza, B., and Hearst, N. (2001) Managed Competition for the poor or poorly managed: Lessons from the Colombian health reform experience. Oxford University Press [http://heapol.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/16/suppl_2/44.pdf] *Ronald L. Numbers (ed.): ''Compulsory Health Insurance: The Continuing American Debate'', Westport, Conn. : Greenwood Press, 1982. *Saltman, R.B., Busse, R. and Figueras, J. (2004) ''Social health insurance systems in western Europe'', Berkshire/New York: Open University Press/McGraw-Hill. {{ISBN|0-335-21363-4}} *Saltman, R.B. and Dubois, H.F.W. (2004) Individual incentive schemes in social health insurance systems, 10(2): 21-25. [http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/LSEHealthAndSocialCare/pdf/eurohealth/Vol10No2.pdf Full text] *Van de Ven, W.P.M.M., Beck, K., Buchner, F. et al. (2003) Risk adjustment and risk selection on the sickness fund market in five European countries, Health Policy, 65(1=: 75-98. *Saltman, R.B. and Dubois, H.F.W. (2005) Current reform proposals in social health insurance countries, Eurohealth, 11(1): 10-14. [http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/LSEHealthAndSocialCare/pdf/eurohealth/vol11No1.pdf Full text] ==External links== * [http://www.healthcareforamericanow.org/ Health Care for America NOW!]. An advocacy group that supports a [[public health insurance option]] for universal health care. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100105142032/http://www.barackobama.com/issues/healthcare/ Health Care Issues & Resources] Barack Obama Website * [http://www.familydoctormag.com/doctors-office/194-doctors-debate-universal-health-care-pros-and-cons-from-the-experts.html Health Debate Pros and Cons] Family Doctor Magazine Website {{Insurance}} [[Category:Health economics]] [[Category:Social programs]] [[Category:Health policy]]

{{distinguish|Occupational burning}} {{Infobox disease |Name = Occupational burn-out |Synonyms = Burn-out |ICD10 = {{ICD10|Z|73|0|z|70}}, {{ICD10|F|43|8}} }} '''Occupational burnout''' is thought to result from long-term, unresolvable, job stress. In 1974, [[Herbert Freudenberger]] became the first researcher to publish in a ''psychology''-related journal a paper that used the term ''burnout''. The paper was based on his observations of the volunteer staff (including himself) at a free clinic for drug addicts.<ref name="staffburnout1">{{cite journal|author=Freudenberger, H.J.|year=1974|title=Staff burnout|journal=Journal of Social Issues|volume= 30|pages=159–165|doi=10.1111/j.1540-4560.1974.tb00706.x}}</ref> He characterized burnout by a set of symptoms that includes exhaustion resulting from work's excessive demands as well as physical symptoms such as headaches and sleeplessness, "quickness to anger" and closed thinking. He observed that the burned-out worker "looks, acts, and seems depressed". After the publication of Freudenberger's original paper, interest in occupational burnout grew. Because the phrase "burnt-out" was part of the title of a 1961 Graham Greene novel, ''A Burnt-Out Case'', which dealt with a doctor working in the Belgian Congo with patients who had leprosy, the phrase may have been in use outside the psychology literature before Freudenberger employed it.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Burnt-Out Case|last=Greene|first=Graham|publisher=William Heinemann Ltd|year=1961|isbn=978-0140185393|pages=cover title}}</ref>
In order to study burnout, a number of researchers developed more focused conceptualizations of burnout. In one conceptualization, job-related burnout is characterized by emotional exhaustion, depersonalization (treating clients/students and colleagues in a cynical way), and reduced feelings of work-related personal accomplishment.<ref name = "Maslach">{{cite journal|authors=Maslach, C., Jackson, S.E, & Leiter, M.P. |title=MBI: The Maslach Burnout Inventory: Manual|publisher= Consulting Psychologists Press|location=Palo Alto|year= 1996|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/277816643}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ruotsalainen|first1=JH|last2=Verbeek|first2=JH|last3=Mariné|first3=A|last4=Serra|first4=C|title=Preventing occupational stress in healthcare workers.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=7 April 2015|issue=4|pages=CD002892|pmid=25847433|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002892.pub5}}</ref> In another conceptualization, burnout is thought to comprise emotional exhaustion, physical fatigue, and cognitive weariness.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Shirom, A., & Melamed, S.|year=2006|title=A comparison of the construct validity of two burnout measures in two groups of professionals|journal=International Journal of Stress Management|volume=13|issue=2|pages=176–200|doi=10.1037/1072-5245.13.2.176}}</ref> A third conceptualization holds that burnout consists of exhaustion and disengagement.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Demerouti | first1 = E | last2 = Bakker | first2 = A.B. | last3 = Vardakou | first3 = I. | last4 = Kantas | first4 = A. | year = 2002 | title = The convergent validity of two burnout instruments: A multitrait-multimethod analysis | url = | journal = European Journal of Psychological Assessment | volume = 18 | issue = 1| pages = 296–307 | doi = 10.1037/a0037726 | pmid = 25151460 }}</ref> The core of the three conceptualizations, as well as Freudenberger's, is exhaustion. Long limited to these dimensions, burnout is now known to involve the full array of depressive symptoms (e.g., low mood, cognitive alterations, sleep disturbance).<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Bianchi, R., Schonfeld, I.S., & Laurent, E.|year=2015|title=Burnout-depression overlap: A review|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|volume=36|pages=28–41|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2015.01.004|pmid=25638755}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = R. | last2 = Schonfeld | first2 = I. S. | last3 = Vandel | first3 = P. | last4 = Laurent | first4 = E. | year = 2017 | title = On the depressive nature of the "burnout syndrome": A clarification | url = | journal = European Psychiatry | volume = 41 | issue = | pages = 109–110 | doi = 10.1016/j.eurpsy.2016.10.008 | pmid = 28135592 }}</ref>
Originally, Maslach and her colleagues focused on burnout within human service professions (e.g., teachers, social workers).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jackson | first1 = S. | last2 = Schwab | first2 = R. | last3 = Schuler | first3 = R. | year = 1986 | title = Toward an understanding of the burnout phenomenon | url = | journal = Journal of Applied Psychology | volume = 71 | issue = 4| pages = 630–640 | doi=10.1037/0021-9010.71.4.630}}</ref> She later expanded the application of burnout to include individuals in many other occupations.<ref name = "Maslach"/>
== Diagnosis == Burnout is not recognized as a distinct disorder in the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM-5]].<ref name="sciammind2">{{cite web|author=Ulrich Kraft|publisher=Scientific American|title=Burned Out|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/burned-out/|date=June 2006|pages=28–33}}</ref> It is included in the [[ICD-10]], but not as a disorder.<ref>ICD-10: International Classification of Diseases. Geneva: World Health Organization, 2015.</ref> It can be found in the ICD under problems related to life-management difficulty (Z73).
In 1981, [[Christina Maslach]] and Susan Jackson developed the first widely used instrument for assessing burnout, namely, the [[Maslach Burnout Inventory]] (MBI).<ref name = "Maslach2">{{cite journal|authors=Maslach, C., & Jackson, S.E.|year=1981|title=The measurement of experienced burnout|journal=Journal of Occupational Behaviour|volume= 2|issue=2|pages=99–113|doi=10.1002/job.4030020205}}</ref> Consistent with Maslach's conceptualization, the MBI operationalizes burnout as a three-dimensional syndrome consisting of emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and reduced personal accomplishment.<ref name = "Maslach2"/><ref name = "Maslach"/> Other researchers have argued that burnout should be limited to fatigue and exhaustion.<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Kristensen|first1 = T.S.|last2 = Borritz|first2 = M.|last3 = Villadsen|first3 = E.|last4 = Christensen|first4 = K.B.|year = 2005|title = The Copenhagen Burnout Inventory: A new tool for the assessment of burnout|url = |journal = Work & Stress|volume = 19|issue = 3|pages = 192–207|doi = 10.1080/02678370500297720}}</ref>
A growing body of evidence suggests that burnout is etiologically, clinically, and [[nosology|nosologically]] similar to [[Major depressive disorder|depression]].<ref>Bianchi, E., Schonfeld, I.S., & Laurent, E. (2018). Burnout syndrome and depression. Y.-K. Kim (Ed.), ''Understanding depression: Volume 2. Clinical manifestations, diagnosis and treatment'' (pp.187-202). Singapore: Springer. doi:10.1007/978-981-10-6577-4_14</ref><ref name = "Ahola">{{cite journal | last1 = Ahola | first1 = K. | last2 = Hakanen | first2 = J. | last3 = Perhoniemi | first3 = R. | last4 = Mutanen | first4 = P. | year = 2014 | title = Relationship between burnout and depressive symptoms: A study using the person-centred approach | url = | journal = Burnout Research | volume = 1 | issue = 1| pages = 29–37 | doi=10.1016/j.burn.2014.03.003}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|authors=Bianchi, R., & Laurent, E. |year=2015|title=Emotional information processing in depression and burnout: An eye-tracking study|journal=European Archives of Psychiatry and Clinical Neuroscience|volume=265|issue=1|pages=27–34|doi=10.1007/s00406-014-0549-x|pmid=25297694}}</ref><ref name="Bianchi, R. 2014">{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = R. | last2 = Schonfeld | first2 = I. S. | last3 = Laurent | first3 = E. | year = 2014 | title = Is burnout a depressive disorder? A re-examination with special focus on atypical depression | url = | journal = International Journal of Stress Management | volume = 21 | issue = 4 | pages = 307–324 | doi=10.1037/a0037906}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal|authors=Bianchi, R., Schonfeld, I. S., & Laurent, E. |title= Is burnout separable from depression in cluster analysis? A longitudinal study|journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology|volume=50|issue= 6|pages= 1005–1111|doi=10.1007/s00127-014-0996-8|pmid= 25527209|year=2014}}</ref><ref name="Hintsa-et-al">{{cite journal|authors=Hintsa, T., Elovainio, M., Jokela, M., Ahola, K., Virtanen, M., & Pirkola, S. |year=2016|title=Is there an independent association between burnout and increased allostatic load? Testing the contribution of psychological distress and depression|journal=Journal of Health Psychology|volume=16|issue=8|pages=576–586|doi= 10.1177/1359105314559619|pmid=25476575|hdl=10138/224473}}</ref><ref name="Schonfeld">{{cite journal|authors=Schonfeld, I.S., & Bianchi, R.|year=2016|title=Burnout and depression: Two entities or one|journal=Journal of Clinical Psychology|volume= 72|issue=1|pages=22–37|doi=10.1002/jclp.22229|pmid=26451877}}</ref> In a study that directly compared depressive symptoms in burned out workers and clinically depressed patients, no diagnostically significant differences were found between the two groups; burned out workers reported as many depressive symptoms as clinically depressed patients.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = R. | last2 = Boffy | first2 = C. | last3 = Hingray | first3 = C. | last4 = Truchot | first4 = D. | last5 = Laurent | first5 = E. | year = 2013 | title = Comparative symptomatology of burnout and depression | url = | journal = Journal of Health Psychology | volume = 18 | issue = 6| pages = 782–787 | doi=10.1177/1359105313481079| pmid = 23520355 }}</ref> Moreover, a study by Bianchi, Schonfeld, and Laurent (2014) showed that about 90% of workers with full-blown burnout meet diagnostic criteria for depression.<ref name="Bianchi, R. 2014"/> The view that burnout is a form of depression has found support in several recent studies.<ref name = "Ahola"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="Hintsa-et-al"/><ref name="Schonfeld"/><ref>{{cite journal|authors=Wurm, W., Vogel, K., Holl, A., Ebner, C., Bayer, D., Mörkl, S., & ... Hofmann, P. |year=2016|title= Depression-burnout overlap in physicians|journal= PLOS ONE|volume= 11|issue= e0149913|pages=e0149913|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0149913|pmid=26930395|pmc=4773131}}</ref>
==Risk factors== Evidence suggests that the etiology of burnout is multifactorial, with dispositional factors playing an important, long-overlooked role.<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Alarcon|first1 = G.|last2 = Eschleman|first2 = K. J.|last3 = Bowling|first3 = N. A.|year = 2009|title = Relationships between personality variables and burnout: A meta-analysis|url = |journal = Work & Stress|volume = 23|issue = 3|pages = 244–263|doi = 10.1080/02678370903282600}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Swider|first1 = B. W.|last2 = Zimmerman|first2 = R. D.|year = 2010|title = Born to burnout: A meta-analytic path model of personality, job burnout, and work outcomes|url = |journal = Journal of Vocational Behavior|volume = 76|issue = 3|pages = 487–506|doi = 10.1016/j.jvb.2010.01.003}}</ref> Cognitive dispositional factors implicated in depression have also been found to be implicated in burnout.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Bianchi, R., & Schonfeld, I.S.|year=2016|title=Burnout is associated with a depressive cognitive style|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume= 100|pages= 1–5|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2016.01.008}}</ref> One cause of burnout includes [[stressor]]s that a person is unable to cope with fully. Occupational burnout often develops slowly and may not be recognized until it has become severe. When one's expectations about a job and its reality differ, burnout can begin.
Burnout is thought to occur when a mismatch is present between the nature of the job and the person doing the job. A common indication of this mismatch is work overload, which sometimes involves a worker who survives a round of layoffs, but after the layoffs the worker finds that he or she is doing too much with too few resources. Overload may occur in the context of downsizing, which often does not narrow an organization's goals, but requires fewer employees to meet those goals.<ref name="Maslach972">{{cite book|authors=Maslach, C. & Leiter, M.P.|title=The Truth About Burnout: How Organizations Cause Personal Stress and What to Do About It|location=New York|publisher=Jossey-Bass|year= 1997}}</ref>
The [[job demands-resources model]] has implications for burnout, as measured by the Oldenburg Burnout Inventory (OLBI). Physical and psychological job demands were concurrently associated with the exhaustion, as measured by the OLBI.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Demerouti|first1=Evangelia|last2=Bakker|first2=Arnold B.|last3=Nachreiner|first3=Friedhelm|last4=Schaufeli|first4=Wilmar B.|title=The job demands-resources model of burnout.|journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|date=2001|volume=86|issue=3|pages=499–512|doi=10.1037/0021-9010.86.3.499}}</ref> Lack of job resources was associated with the disengagement component of the OLBI.
Maslach, Schaufeli and Leiter identified six risk factors for burnout: mismatch in workload, mismatch in control, lack of appropriate awards, loss of a sense of positive connection with others in the workplace, perceived lack of fairness, and conflict between values.<ref name="Maslach01">{{cite journal|last1 = Maslach|first1 = C.|last2 = Schaufeli|first2 = W. B.|last3 = Leiter|first3 = M. P.|editor = S. T. Fiske |editor2=D. L. Schacter |editor3=C. Zahn-Waxler|year = 2001|title = Job burnout|journal = Annual Review of Psychology|volume = 52|pages = 397–422|doi = 10.1146/annurev.psych.52.1.397|pmid = 11148311}}</ref>
Burnout is supposed to be a work-specific syndrome. However, this restrictive view of burnout's scope has been shown to be groundless.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bianchi | first1 = R. | last2 = Truchot | first2 = D. | last3 = Laurent | first3 = E. | last4 = Brisson | first4 = R. | last5 = Schonfeld | first5 = I. S. | year = 2014 | title = Is burnout solely job-related? A critical comment | url = | journal = Scandinavian Journal of Psychology | volume = 55 | issue = 4| pages = 357–361 | doi=10.1111/sjop.12119| pmid = 24749783 }}</ref> In other words, burnout could apply to nonwork roles such as that of caregiver or student.
==Effects== Some research indicates that burnout is associated with reduced [[job performance]], coronary [[heart disease]],<ref>{{cite journal|author=Toker, S., Melamed, S., Berliner, S., Zeltser, D., & Shapira, I.|year=2012|title=Burnout and risk of coronary heart disease: a prospective study of 8838 employees|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|volume= 74|issue=8|pages=840–847|doi=10.1097/PSY.0b013e31826c3174|pmid=23006431}}</ref> and [[mental health]] problems (although note the abovementioned research that suggests it is a depressive syndrome, e.g., Ahola et al., 2005<ref name = "Ahola"/>). Chronic burnout is also associated with cognitive impairments such as [[memory]] and [[attention]].<ref>{{cite journal|last = Sandstrom|first = A|author2 = Rhodin IN|author3 = Lundberg M|author4 = Olsson T|author5 = Nyberg L.|title = Impaired cognitive performance in patients with chronic burnout sysndrome.|journal = Biological Psychology|year = 2005|volume = 69|issue = 3|pages = 271–279|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301051104001553|accessdate = December 5, 2012|doi = 10.1016/j.biopsycho.2004.08.003|pmid = 15925030}}</ref> Occupational burnout is also associated with absences, time missed from work, and thoughts of quitting.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal | last1 = Elliott | first1 = T. | last2 = Shewchuk | first2 = R. | last3 = Hagglund | first3 = K. | last4 = Rybarczyk | first4 = B. | last5 = Harkins | first5 = S. | year = 1996 | title = Occupational burnout, tolerance for stress, and coping among nurses in rehabilitation units | url = | journal = Rehabilitation Psychology | volume = 41 | issue = 4| pages = 267–284 | doi=10.1037/0090-5550.41.4.267}}</ref>
==Treatment and prevention==
=== At the individual level === It is difficult to treat the three symptoms of exhaustion, cynicism, and inefficacy, as they react to the same preventive or treatment activities in different ways.<ref name="Hätinen-2007">{{cite journal | last1 = Hätinen | first1 = M. | last2 = Kinnunen | first2 = U. | last3 = Pekkonen | first3 = M. | last4 = Kalimo | first4 = R. | year = 2007 | title = Comparing two burnout interventions: Perceived job control mediates decreases in burnout | url = | journal = International Journal of Stress Management | volume = 14 | issue = 3| pages = 227–248 | doi=10.1037/1072-5245.14.3.227}}</ref> Exhaustion is more easily treated than cynicism and professional inefficacy, which tend to be more resistant to treatment. Research shows that intervention actually may worsen the professional efficacy of one who originally had low professional efficacy.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Van Dierendonck | first1 = D. | last2 = Schaufeli | first2 = W. B. | last3 = Buunk | first3 = B. P. | year = 1998 | title = The evaluation of an individual burnout intervention program: The role of inequity and social support | url = | journal = Journal of Applied Psychology | volume = 83 | issue = 3| pages = 392–407 | doi=10.1037/0021-9010.83.3.392}}</ref>
For the purpose of preventing occupational burnout, various stress management interventions have been shown to help improve employee health and well-being in the workplace and lower stress levels. Training employees in ways to manage stress in the workplace have also proven effective in prevention of burnout.<ref>{{cite book|author=William D. McLaurine|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uRU3tG29VfUC&lpg=PA92&dq=job%20burnout%20prevention&pg=PA92#v=onepage&q&f=false|title= A correlational study of job burnout and organizational commitment among correctional officers|publisher= Capella University. School of Psychology|page= 92|isbn=9780549438144}}</ref> One study suggest that social-cognitive processes such as [[organizational commitment|commitment]] to work, [[self-efficacy]], learned resourcefulness and [[hope]] may insulate individuals from experiencing occupational burnout.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> Increased [[Job control (workplace)|job control]] is another intervention shown to help counteract exhaustion and [[cynicism (contemporary)|cynicism]] in the workplace.<ref name="Hätinen-2007" />
Burnout prevention programs have traditionally focused on [[cognitive-behavioral therapy]] (CBT), [[cognitive restructuring]], didactic [[stress management]], and relaxation. CBT, [[relaxation technique]]s (including physical techniques and mental techniques), and schedule changes are the best-supported techniques for reducing and preventing burnout in a health-care specific setting. Combining both organizational and individual level activities may be the most beneficial approach to reduce symptoms. A Cochrane review reported that evidence for the efficacy of CBT in healthcare workers is of low quality, indicating that it is no better than alternative interventions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ruotsalainen|first1=JH|last2=Verbeek|first2=JH|last3=Mariné|first3=A|last4=Serra|first4=C|title=Preventing occupational stress in healthcare workers.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=7 April 2015|issue=4|pages=CD002892|pmid=25847433|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002892.pub5}}</ref>
Employee rehabilitation is a tertiary preventive intervention which means the strategies used in rehabilitation are meant to alleviate, as well as prevent, burnout symptoms.<ref name="Hätinen-2007" /> Such rehabilitation of the working population includes multidisciplinary activities with the intent of maintaining and improving employees' working ability and ensuring a supply of skilled and capable labor in society.
Additional prevention methods include: starting the day with a relaxing ritual; adopting healthy eating, exercising, and sleeping habits; setting boundaries; taking breaks from technology; nourishing one's creative side, and learning how to manage stress.<ref name="pat">{{cite web |url=http://health.usnews.com/health-care/for-better/articles/2017-02-27/politically-active-4-tips-for-incorporating-self-care |title=Politically Active? 4 Tips for Incorporating Self-Care, US News |date=27 February 2017 |work=US News |accessdate=5 March 2017 }}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA2">{{cite web|authors=Smith, M., Segal, R., & Segal, J.|year=2014|title=Stress Symptoms, Signs, & Causes: The Effects of Stress Overload and What You Can Do About It|accessdate=31 March 2014|url=http://www.helpguide.org/mental/stress_signs.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140927114835/http://www.helpguide.org/mental/stress_signs.htm|archivedate=27 September 2014}}</ref>
=== At the organizational level === While individuals can [[Coping (psychology)|cope]] with the symptoms of burnout, the only way to truly prevent burnout is through a combination of organizational change and education for the individual.<ref name="Maslach972"/>
Maslach and Leiter postulated that burnout occurs when there is a disconnection between the organization and the individual with regard to what they called the six areas of work life: workload, control, reward, community, fairness, and values.<ref name="Maslach01"/> Resolving these discrepancies requires integrated action on the part of both the individual and the organization.<ref name="Maslach01" /> A better connection on workload means assuring adequate resources to meet demands as well as [[Work–life balance|work/life balances]] that encourage employees to revitalize their energy.<ref name="Maslach01" /> A better connection on values means clear organizational values to which employees can feel committed.<ref name="Maslach01" /> A better connection on community means supportive leadership and relationships with colleagues rather than discord.<ref name="Maslach01" />
One approach for addressing these discrepancies focuses specifically on the fairness area. In one study employees met weekly to discuss and attempt to resolve perceived inequities in their job.<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = van Dierendonck|first1 = D.|last2 = Schaufeli|first2 = W. B.|last3 = Buunk|first3 = B. P.|year = 1998|title = The evaluation of an individual burnout intervention program: the role of in- equity and social support|url = |journal = J. Appl. Psychol.|volume = 83|issue = 3|pages = 392–407|doi = 10.1037/0021-9010.83.3.392}}</ref> The intervention was associated with decreases in exhaustion over time but not cynicism or inefficacy, suggesting that a broader approach is required.<ref name="Maslach01" />

The '''Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantifications System''' ('''POP-Q'''), is a system of assessing the degree of prolapse of pelvic organs to help standardize diagnosing, comparing, documenting, and sharing of clinical findings.<ref name=persu>{{Cite journal|last=Persu|first=C|last2=Chapple|first2=CR|last3=Cauni|first3=V|last4=Gutue|first4=S|last5=Geavlete|first5=P|date=2011-02-15|title=Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification System (POP–Q) – a new era in pelvic prolapse staging|journal=Journal of Medicine and Life|volume=4|issue=1|pages=75–81|issn=1844-122X|pmc=3056425|pmid=21505577|via=}}</ref><ref name=barb/> This assessment is used the most frequently.<ref name="harr">{{Cite journal|last=Beckley|first=Ian|last2=Harris|first2=Neil|date=2013-03-26|title=Pelvic organ prolapse: a urology perspective|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/2051415812472675|journal=Journal of Clinical Urology|language=en|volume=6|issue=2|pages=68–76|doi=10.1177/2051415812472675}}</ref><ref name = boyd>{{Cite journal|last=Boyd|first=S. S.|last2=O'Sullivan|first2=D. M.|last3=Tulikangas|first3=P.|date=2017-03-01|title=29: Implementation of the pelvic organ prolapse quantification system in peer-reviewed journals|url=http://www.ajog.org/article/S0002-9378(16)46366-0/fulltext|journal=American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology|language=English|volume=216|issue=3|pages=S591|doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2016.12.076|issn=0002-9378}}</ref> More research publications related to [[pelvic organ prolapse]] use the POP-Q as the measure of pelvic organ prolapse.<ref name = boyd/>
[[Pelvic organ prolapse]], when assessed using the POP-Q, identifies the prevalence of pelvic organ prolapse to be up to 50% while diagnosis by symptoms has a prevalence of 3–6%.<ref name=barb/> Some advocate that the system of assessment be modified.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Oyama|first=Ian A.|last2=Steinberg|first2=Adam C.|last3=Watai|first3=Travis K.|last4=Minaglia|first4=Steven M.|title=Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification Use in the Literature|url=http://content.wkhealth.com/linkback/openurl?sid=WKPTLP:landingpage&an=01436319-201201000-00010|journal=Female Pelvic Medicine & Reconstructive Surgery|volume=18|issue=1|pages=33–34|doi=10.1097/spv.0b013e31823bd1ab}}</ref>
The POP-Q was developed in 1996 and it quantifies the descent of pelvic organs into the vagina.<ref name="harr" /><ref name=hoff >{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/779244257|title=Williams gynecology|date=2012|publisher=McGraw-Hill Medical|last1=Hoffman |first1=Barbara L. |last2=Williams |first2=J. Whitridge |author2-link=John Whitridge Williams |isbn=9780071716727|edition=2nd|location=New York|pages=647–653|oclc=779244257}}</ref><ref name=barb/> The POP-Q provides reliable description of the support of the anterior, posterior and apical vaginal wall. It uses objective and precise distance measurements to the reference point, the hymen. Cystocele and prolapse of the vagina from other causes is staged using POP-Q criteria can range from good support (no descent into the vagina) reported as a POP-Q stage 0 or I to a POP-Q score of IV; which includes prolapse beyond the hymen. It also used to quantifies the movement of other structures into the vaginal lumen and their descent.<ref name=hoff /><ref name = barb>{{Cite journal|last=Barber|first=Matthew D.|last2=Maher|first2=Christopher|date=2013-11-01|title=Epidemiology and outcome assessment of pelvic organ prolapse|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00192-013-2169-9|journal=International Urogynecology Journal|language=en|volume=24|issue=11|pages=1783–1790|doi=10.1007/s00192-013-2169-9|issn=0937-3462}}</ref>
== Stages == [[Image:Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification System.svg|thumb|250px|right|<center>'''POP-Q points'''</center>]]
{| class="wikitable" border="1" |+ Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification System (POP-Q) ! Stage !! Description |- | 0 || No prolapse anterior and posterior points are all −3 cm, and C or D is between −TVL and −(TVL−2) cm. |- | 1 || The criteria for stage 0 are not met, and the most distal prolapse is more than 1 cm above the level of the hymen (less than −1 cm). |- | 2 || The most distal prolapse is between 1 cm above and 1 cm below the hymen (at least one point is −1, 0, or +1). |- | 3 || The most distal prolapse is more than 1 cm below the hymen but no further than 2 cm less than TVL. |- | 4 || Represents complete procidentia or vault eversion; the most distal prolapse protrudes to at least (TVL−2) cm. |}
The POP-Q assessment tool measures nine points in the vagina. The [[hymen]] is the reference point to which the other points are compared. The prolapsed organs are measured in centimeters to the hymen. The measurements are taken when the [[Valsalva maneuver|Valsalva maneuve]]<nowiki/>r is performed by the woman while in the dorsal lithotomy position.<ref name="medscape">{{Cite web|url=https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/814321_2?pa=B35LncSjNvX/jiw6dzfOYAIGa/Lq1tRP5XyOfPcs7ZqgM3E57VzsrmFFvo8kusb356MI7dGTgNawPfsOtJla9Q==|title=Urogynecological Risk Assessment in Postmenopausal Women|last1=Sengupta|first1=Niladri|last2=Hilliard|first2=Timothy|date=2013|website=www.medscape.com|accessdate=2017-12-29}}</ref><ref name="harr" /> The anatomical landmarks used are anterior vaginal wall, [[cervix]], hymen, [[Perineum|perineal body]], total vaginal length, posterior vaginal wall and [[Vaginal fornix|posterior fornix]].<ref name =racgp>{{Cite web|url=https://www.racgp.org.au/afp/2015/july/pelvic-organ-prolapse-%E2%80%93-a-review/|title=RACGP – Pelvic organ prolapse – a review|last=Practitioners|first=The Royal Australian College of General|website=www.racgp.org.au|language=English|accessdate=2017-12-29}}</ref> A three by three centimeter grid is used to record the proximal and distal numbers. The information on the grid is translated to the appropriate stage of prolapse.<ref name="harr" />
This system of assessing pelvic organ prolapse is currently used widely in China and the US.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wang|first=Yi-ting|last2=Jiang|first2=Jun-ying|last3=Han|first3=Jin-song|date=2016-02-01|title=A review of the pelvic organ prolapse quantification system in China|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00192-015-2830-6|journal=International Urogynecology Journal|language=en|volume=27|issue=2|pages=287–290|doi=10.1007/s00192-015-2830-6|issn=0937-3462}}</ref>
== Other assessments == Other assessment tools are also used to determine the impact of pelvic floor prolapse. These are Pelvic Floor Impact Questionnaire (PFIQ),The Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory (PFDI) and the shorter forms PFIQ-7 and PFDI-20.<ref name="medscape" /> 
The evaluation of pelvic organ prolapse includes other diagnostic tests in addition to the POP-Q. These can be:<ref name="harr" /> * voiding [[cystometry]] * [[ultrasound]] * defecating [[proctography]] * [[anorectal manometry|anal manometry]] * [[electromyography]] * [[magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]]
In the US, greater than 200,000 [[surgery|surgeries]] are performed each year for pelvic organ prolapse. Examples of pelvic organ prolapse are [[cystocele]], [[rectocele]], [[urethrocele]], [[enterocele]] and [[sigmoidocele]]. Cystocele is the most common.<ref name="umek">{{Cite journal|last=Halpern-Elenskaia|first=Ksenia|last2=Umek|first2=Wolfgang|last3=Bodner-Adler|first3=Barbara|last4=Hanzal|first4=Engelbert|date=2017-12-06|title=Anterior colporrhaphy: a standard operation? Systematic review of the technical aspects of a common procedure in randomized controlled trials|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00192-017-3510-5|journal=International Urogynecology Journal|language=en|pages=1–8|doi=10.1007/s00192-017-3510-5|issn=0937-3462}}</ref><ref name="barb" /> In the UK, urologists can specialize in female urology and treat prolapse.<ref name="harr" /><ref name="persu" />
== History == Other assessments have been developed. The Porges or Severity prolapse assessment system was proposed in 1963. <ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y5cYRhGJsOsC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41&dq=rugae+vaginal&source=bl&ots=_aB0zfSH_H&sig=4bxHBjHfuWtdR361qDUs0m--GNA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAwZmh5KfZAhVNhq0KHf6WCX04ChDoAQhVMAc#v=onepage&q=rugae%20vaginal&f=false|title=Vaginal Surgery for Incontinence and Prolapse|last=Zimmern|first=Philippe E.|last2=Haab|first2=Francois|last3=Chapple|first3=Christopher R.|date=2007-12-09|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|year=|isbn=9781846283468|location=|pages=40|language=en}}</ref> In 1972, [[the Baden–Walker Halfway Scoring System]] was developed and is the second most used system.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="persu" /> In 1980, the Beecham system was developed. The POP was developed in 1996.<ref name=":0" />

= The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews | volume = 4 | pages = CD004905 | date = April 2017 | pmid = 28407219 | doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD004905.pub5 }}</ref> | prognosis = | frequency = 213
